It is said according to the legend that he cut it off to the giant Druoon Antigoon, because this demanded a toll on all captains of ships that passed by there, if not, he cut off his hand. There is also a legend which says that this statue was built in honor of the Congolese since with the arrival of the Belgians in the Republic of the Congo, they had the habit of cutting off the hands of anyone who did not colaborate.

properties.name: Zeebrugge Port
properties.description: On several occasions, Zeebrugge also served as the port of departure for the fleet of Congo ships of the ‘Compagnie Maritime Belge’. This proved that Zeebrugge could receive the largest ships in spite of the silting problems with which the port was confronted. In 1929 however, the Belgian government decided to bear the expenses of the dredging operations in all Belgian ports, which resulted in more financial breathing space for the Port authority.

properties.name: Colonial Pioneers-Etterbeek
properties.description:
{{https://d2fik7qifeewcl.cloudfront.net/images/big/617.jpg?1361805944}}

“To the men from Etterbeek, pioneers of civilisation who died in the Congo 1876-1908”

properties.name: Memorial fountain for Pierre Ponthier
properties.description:
{{http://koregos.org/Koregos/documents/Fig137248.jpg}}


In the heart of Marche-en-Famenne, in the place currently known as King Albert, stands an impressive fountain, in the center of which stands the bust of Major Pierre Ponthier (Ouffet 1858 - Kassongo 1893). Inaugurated in 1897, the monument is the work of Alphonse de Tombay (Liège 1843 - Liège 1918). This communal initiative meets a triple concern. First, to highlight the technical and social progress that is the provision of drinking water to the inhabitants of the locality; other municipalities of Wallonia also opted, in the nineteenth century, for a monument-fountain dedicated to a "local" historical figure: this is the second objective pursued: to pay homage to a child from the country who died in combat in the Congo. Finally, it is also about venerating a hero who lost his life in a feat of arms intended to free slaves. The postcards representing the monument circulating at the beginning of the 20th century emphasize the anti-slavery campaign then waged by the independent state of Congo.

properties.name: Memorial plaque to Nicolas Hardy (missioner in Congo)
properties.description: {{https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/74/Elsaute_Nicolas_Hardy.jpg}}

properties.name: Monument à Léopold II
Monument aux Pioneers au Congo
properties.description:
{{https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Monument_aux_pionniers_belges_au_Congo_01.JPG/1200px-Monument_aux_pionniers_belges_au_Congo_01.JPG}}

This monument commemorate the explorers, missionaries and soldiers who worked for the colonization of the Congo.

The monument was designed by the sculptor Thomas Vinçotte, whose signature is found on the lower right.

Commissioned in 1911, two years after the death of King Leopold II, the monument will be completed in 1921, because of the First World War. Although contemporary with the appearance of expressionism and modernism, the work is clearly related to the pre-war world.

It is the subject of a classification as historical monuments since November 18, 1976 in the same way as the entire Park Cinquantenaire.

properties.name: Monument aux Troupes des Campagnes d’Afrique
properties.description:
{{http://bel-memorial.org/cities/bruxelles-brussel/schaerbeek/schaerbeek_mon_campagnes_afrique_1.jpg}}


This monument was erected in 1970 at the initiative of URFRACOL. URFRACOL was formed in 1958 by the merger of two Fraternals formed after the Second World War: the Fraternelle des Anciens of the Abyssinian Campaign and the Union of Fraternals of the Expeditionary Forces of the Belgian Congo (Madagascar, Nigeria, Middle East and Burma). South African Air Force and Royal Air Force alumni trained in South Africa were added. In the end, the former members of the Force Publique, almost all of them War volunteers, completed his squad. this monument is bloomed every year twice.

properties.name: Monument of king Leopold II
properties.description:
{{https://imperialglobalexeter.files.wordpress.com/2016/06/cullen1.png}}
A statue near the Royal Palace was paintbombed with pink paint last night. King Leopold II is linked to the colonial past, when Congo was called 'his privet garden'. King is repeatedly accused of 10 million deaths in time of the colonization

properties.name: Monument to 1908 annexation of the Congo
properties.description:
{{https://s3-media3.fl.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/XdpjccGA-t41atYEhLs9YQ/ls.jpg}}



Memorial monument for the annexation of Belgian Congo, after a design by city architect Emiel Van Averbeke, and the sculptors Jules Baetes and Jan Kerckx, founded in 1911.

The memorial commemorates the annexation of the Congo Free State, a sovereign state since 1885 on the private initiative of King Leopold II, by the Kingdom of Belgium and the creation of the Belgian-Congo colony. This was decided by the Chamber and Senate on 18 October 1908, partly as a result of a report by an international parliamentary committee of inquiry into charges of abuse, forced labor and repression. The initiative to set up the memorial originated from the Chamber of Commerce of Antwerp, which had already organized a procession in the presence of Leopold II on June 6, 1909 in response to the "Congonaasting". The designer of this procession Jules Baetes, who had made two commemorative tokens on the occasion, was subsequently also commissioned to commemorate a memorial monument with sculpture by him. Emiel Van Averbeke was responsible for the architectural elaboration, and Jan Kerckx for the ornamental sculpture. The Congo monument was completed on 28 September 1911 and transferred to the Antwerp city council on 8 October, which was then responsible for planting and the wrought iron gate, finished on 30 March 1914.

High granite obelisk, which is constricted from a square base with side pieces to an elegant needle. The base, decorated with bronze volutes and garlands, bears the crowned portrait medallion of Leopold II on the front, and the Mercury emblem on the back as a symbol for the Chamber of Commerce, including text plates with the order in Dutch and French, all also from bronze. The top, with a bronze star on the four sides representing the flag of Belgian Congo, is crowned by a bronze capital with the coat of arms of Antwerp, horned mask heads, meanders and garlands as decoration. The original gilt bronze Mercury statue, modeled after the famous 16th-century bronze statue of Giovanni da Bologna, rests on it. The naked Mercury is depicted with a winged helmet and sandals, with the tip of the left foot resting on a sphere, the Mercury staff in the left arm, the right arm forwards and the right leg extended backwards. The monument is surrounded by a rectangular flowerbed with quarter-rounded corners, trimmed with a wrought-iron balustrade in neo-Louis XVI style in which the monogram with double L of Leopold II is integrated on all four sides, on a bluestone skirting.

properties.name: Monument to general Albert Thys
properties.description:
{{https://fr.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fichier:Monument_au_G%C3%A9n%C3%A9ral_Thys_01.JPG}}


The monument celebrates the memory of General Albert Thys (1849-1915), pioneer of Belgian colonial enterprises in the Congo, and faithful auxiliary of King Leopold II of Belgium in these companies.

Designed in 1920 by the sculptor Thomas Vinçotte, the monument is made by his colleague Frans Huygelen and inaugurated in 1926, after the death of Vinçotte, who died in 1925.

It is the subject of a classification as historical monuments since November 18, 1976 in the same way as the entire Park Cinquantenaire.

properties.name: Monument to the Colonial Pioneers of Ixelles
Nègres marrons surpris par des chiens
properties.description:
{{http://www.irismonument.be/medias/buildings/10516085_A006_P01.jpg}}

Carrara marble sculpture (after a plaster from 1869), by the sculptor Louis Samain. Acquired by the Belgian State in 1894 and offered to the City, it was placed on the Avenue in 1895, date of signature. Blue stone pedestal, octagon with curved sides, designed by the architect E. Le Graive.
The poignant scene - a black slave and her child attacked by two mastiffs - is inspired by Harriet Beecher-Stowe's famous novel, Uncle Tom's Cabin (1851).

This monument in Ixelles, there is almost nothing mentioned, only the year and the sculptor. It is inspired on a book about slavery. 
What represented is a Negre Marrón, that are people who fought from the plantations to “go back to the savagery”. In the Palace of Justice is still the same statue. The question is; which message they want to give if the statue is still there?

properties.description: {{http://lh3.googleusercontent.com/iobXlzZiILLPrW0M99zH7_MR-4f2r4TPtUzn-Qu69CT2CNVV0TSj7mjdKiovnMoi29MQoJvHvqePclsQnoOsqFvO7wig=s1024}}

properties.name: Plaque: The Belgian Dinasty and the Congo
Statue de Leopold II
properties.description: {{https://statues.vanderkrogt.net/Foto/be/beha012-2.jpg}}

properties.name: The invisible hand (Maarten Vanden Eynde)
properties.description:
{{http://www.maartenvandeneynde.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Maarten-Vanden-Eynde-The-Invisible-Hand-Art-Brussels.jpg}}

The Invisible Hand is a rubber copy of the right hand of Leopold II, taken at night from the sculpture by Thomas Vinçotte made in 1926, located at the Regentlaan in Brussels, Belgium. The constructed mould was taken to a former rubber plantation in Kasai-Occidental in the Democratic Republic of Congo and filled up with natural rubber. The rubber hand was presented at the art fair Art Brussels, completing the problematic circle of colonial treasure hunting in relation to historical fetishisation.

The Invisible Hand refers both to the theory of Adam Smith, who described in 1759 in The Theory of Moral Sentiments the self regulating effect of a market economy in which everyone strives for personal gain and profit, and as a result infuses the entire economy and creates a collective welfare. Leopold II used his so-called philanthropic International African Association (1877 – 1879) and later the Congo Free State (1885 –1908) to pillage the available natural resources. The ironic and macabre result is that by doing so, he indeed 'unwillingly' instigated a local economic growth, but at a high price. More than 10 million people are estimated to have died as a consequence of Leopolds 'Invisible Hand’.

At the other hand, The Invisible Hand points at the horrible custom of chopping of innumerable hands of enslaved people to ensure the demanded rubber quota.

properties.name: The Triumphal Arch (Parc of the Cinquantenaire)
properties.description:
{{https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Brussels_Cinquantenaire_R02.jpg/2560px-Brussels_Cinquantenaire_R02.jpg}}

Most buildings of the U-shaped complex which dominate the park were commissioned by the Belgian government under the patronage of King Leopold II for the 1880 National Exhibition commemorating the fiftieth anniversary of Belgian independence. During successive exhibitions in the same area, more structures were added. The centrepiece triumphal arch was erected in 1905 replacing a previous temporary version of the arcade by Gédéon Bordiau. The structures were built in iron, glass and stone, symbolising the economic and industrial performance of Belgium. The surrounding 30-hectare park esplanade was full of picturesque gardens, ponds and waterfalls. It housed several trade fairs, exhibitions and festivals at the beginning of the century. In 1930 the government decided to reserve Cinquantenaire for use as a leisure park.
{{https://thumbs.dreamstime.com/z/monumento-anti-de-la-esclavitud-en-blankenberge-b%C3%A9lgica-46437855.jpg}}

“To the men from Etterbeek, pioneers of civilisation who died in the Congo 1876-1908”

Location: On birth home of the Dryepondt family, Wollestraat, facing Belfry of Bruges.

[[https://books.google.be/books?id=7cOr7D-HHBsC&pg=PA107&lpg=PA107&dq=Gustave+Dryepondt&source=bl&ots=6loD9Ry799&sig=ACfU3U2PtiDKwVmdVjrVDl9FqWTMgO4DKg&hl=nl&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwju6pmr8sDiAhUFK1AKHf8pBrwQ6AEwBXoECAkQAQ#v=onepage&q=Gustave%20Dryepondt&f=false]]
properties.name: Gustave Dryepondt - Statue
Leopold II
properties.description:
Leopold II was born in Brussels, on April 9, 1835.

He was the second king of the Belgians and the owner of the Free State of the Congo. His reign began on December 17, 1865.

His reign ended on December 17, 1909 the day he died.

properties.name: Leopold II
properties.description: Leopoldo's ideas about colonialism were clear, he was very ambitious and wanted to have everything and colonize everything. If he did good things, it was for him to be rewarded that in the future he could use to become a multimillionaire and be a great colonizer.

properties.name: Leopold II
properties.description:
Thanks to the colonization of the Congo, Leopold turned Belgium into an imperialist power and himself into a billionaire.

A large part of the territories that Leopold II had colonized in Africa constitute the current State of the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

properties.name: Port of Antwerp
properties.description: This Port  is in the heart of Europe accessible to capesize ships. It is Europe’s second-largest seaport, after Rotterdam.

properties.name: Monument to Leopold II
properties.description: [[https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/35/Leopold_II_statue_Auderghem.JPG]]

properties.name: Port of Antwerp
properties.description:
This Port  is in the heart of Europe accessible to capesize ships. It is Europe’s second-largest seaport, after Rotterdam. 

The influence of the Congo on Belgium has been manifested mainly in economic terms: through the activities of the Union Minière (now Umicore), the development of a nonferrous metal industry, and the development of the Port of Antwerp and diamond industry (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belgian_Congo)

properties.name: Standbeel Leopold II
properties.description:
[[https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q56054913#/media/File:Ekeren_(B)_-_Markt_Standbeeld_leopold_II.jpg]] 

The statue was erected in 1885 as a reminder of King Leopold's visit to Ekeren and has therefore been at a central location in Ekeren for almost 150 years

properties.name: Art Decó
properties.description:
The building was erected in 1927 for Gerard Koninckx Frères an exotic fruit wholesalers by Eugene Dhuicque.
Multiple banana motifs (comes from Congo) can be seen and for a good reason, this is the fruit that made the fortune of many merchants in the beginning of the 20th century.

properties.name: Compagnie Maritime Belge
properties.description: CMB was founded in 1895 under the name Compagnie Belge Maritime du Congo (CBMC). At the request of Leopold II of Belgium and with support from British investors, a maritime connection was opened with Congo Free State. On 6 February 1895 the CMB ship Léopoldville was the first to leave port of Antwerp for Congo Free State. For sixty years the Congo boats  were a constant presence in the port of Antwerp.

properties.name: Compagnie Maritime Belge du Congo
properties.description:
The first boat under Belgian flag to leave Antwerp was Leopoldville 1. Successive contracts between CBMC and the Congo Free State required faster rotational speeds, which led the company to regularly replace its vessels with newer units.
During the First World War, the decline in British, French and Portuguese tonnage to the Belgian Congo as a result of the submarine war, combined with the growth of Congolese exports, led to an accumulation of stocks in Congolese ports

properties.name: Independence of the Congo
properties.description: The independence of the Congo in 1960 and its consequences were hard on the CMB (belgium maritime company). Not only freight transport fell, but people preferred to take the plane to the ship to move. Armement Deppe was bought in 1960, until then the second largest Belgian shipping company. AD survives as a separate company until 1984. This is partly due to cargo rights in Central and South America. The boats are being gradually replaced. CMB was now less dependent on shipping from Africa.

properties.name: Kuumba (art place)
properties.description: This place is a Flemish-African cultural center in Matongé, teaches traditional African dances, music and languages. In this particular dance class, a group of students performs a dance routine to a rapt, predominantly Congolese audience. The Congolese art is still present in Belgium

properties.name: Lloyd Royal Belge
properties.description:
Lloyd Royal Belge was found on 26 June 1916 by the Belgian government.

In 1930, CMBC took over the Lloyd Royal Belge and it had fallen into difficult papers due to the collapse of freight rates and was an ideal acquisition candidate for CMBC. With a new name Compagnie Maritime Belge (Lloyd Royal), the company became the largest Belgian shipowner with 38 ships.  Thanks to the support of the Belgian government, the shipping company managed to regain its former impetus. New ships were built and there was no longer just sailing on Africa. From now on ports in North and South America and the Far East were also visited.

properties.name: Ostende port
properties.description:
Ostend, happened to take the consideration of city in 1265, because before this, it was only a small town, where the main economic source was fishing.
In 1395, the inhabitants of Ostend, decided to move the city to a safer place, after the great dikes, but without losing the territory of the port, where it received large imports from other countries, most significantly from the Republic of the Congo.

properties.name: Port of Boma
properties.description:
Boma was founded as a slaving station and entrepôt by merchants of several European countries in the 16th century. Trade was chiefly in the hands of Dutch merchants. No European power exercised sovereignty, though claims were from time to time put forward by Portugal.
In 1884 the people of Boma were forced to 'grant' a protectorate of their country to the International Association of the Congo, made up of European powers. In 1886 King Leopold of Belgium established the Congo Free State, designating Boma as its capital. He ran the state as his personal fiefdom for several years, nearly enslaving many Congolese with a private military, and abusing them to force rubber production. International outrage and action by the Belgian legislature resulted in the government taking over supervision of what was established as the colony of the Belgian Congo.

properties.name: Silvio Bravo´s Statue
properties.description:
There are many stories about this statue located in the central square of Antwerp. In it appears Silvio Bravo, Roman centurion, which carries a hand. It is said according to the legend that he cut it off to the giant Druoon Antigoon, because this demanded a toll on all captains of ships that passed by there, if not, he cut off his hand. There is also a legend which says that this statue was built in honor of the Congolese since with the arrival of the Belgians in the Republic of the Congo, they had the habit of cutting off the hands of anyone who did not colaborate. 


TOURISTS VISITING THE PRETTY GROTE Markt of Antwerp are always impressed by the extravagant 16th-century city hall and guildhalls that surround the historic main square. And then they take a closer look at the central fountain, which for those unfamiliar with local legend is quite a peculiar sight: a naked man in the act of throwing a huge severed hand.

The Brabo Fountain (Brabofontein in Dutch) is a tribute to the mythical Roman soldier Silvius Brabo. According to legend, there was once a giant named Druon Antigoon who built a fortress along the Scheldt River. The giant forced passing boats to pay a toll, as well as anyone crossing the nearby bridge. If the travelers refused, Antigoon cut off one of their hands and tossed it into the river.

The giant’s reign of extortion came to an end when Silvius Brabo sailed down river. He refused to pay the giant’s toll, and challenged the giant to a duel. Brabo was victorious, and chopped off the giant’s head as well as his hand, which he threw into the river just like the giant once did.

According to folklore, the name Antwerp—or Antwerpen in Dutch— came from this very legend, with Antwerpen in Flemish and hand werpen in Dutch both meaning “hand throwing.” This has been contested by etymologists, but the legend nonetheless is much celebrated in the city, as evidenced by the fountain and Antwerp’s famous chocolate hands.

The sculpture of Brabo depicts the soldier as he throws the giant’s hand in the river, water spouting out of the severed wrist like blood. Brabo stands on a tall pedestal decorated with an array of creatures, including fish, a sea lion, a turtle, a dragon-like monster and some mermaids holding up a castle, symbolizing Antwerp. And beneath the feet of Silvius Brabo is the severed head of the giant Antigoon, the slain scourge of the now liberated river.

The statue was designed by the Belgian sculptor Jef Lambeaux and inaugurated in 1887. It was placed at the center of the Grote Markt, in a prime location in front of the city hall. Not only did it represent the legend of Silvius Brabo, it was also a symbolic celebration of the freeing of the Scheldt River. For more than a century, the Dutch had been demanding tolls from ships passing along the river, severely hampering the growth of Antwerp. Finally, in 1863, the Dutch stopped demanding tolls (with no dismemberment necessary), a cause for much celebration in Antwerp. 

https://www.atlasobscura.com/places/brabo-fountain

properties.name: Zeebrugge Port
properties.description: On several occasions, Zeebrugge also served as the port of departure for the fleet of Congo ships of the ‘Compagnie Maritime Belge’. This proved that Zeebrugge could receive the largest ships in spite of the silting problems with which the port was confronted. In 1929 however, the Belgian government decided to bear the expenses of the dredging operations in all Belgian ports, which resulted in more financial breathing space for the Port authority.

properties.description: GKF Gerard Koninck Freres

properties.name: Gérard Koninckx Frères Building
GKF Building
properties.description:
Gérard Koninxck Frères or GKF is a fruit company that profited from importing bananas from Congo. They built several trade buildings in Art Nouveau style, for example this one on the Boulevard d'Ypres, decorated with golden bananas. This area is close to the canal where the boats with imported fruits arrived.

{{http://www.brusselspictures.com/wp-content/photos/ColonialArt/thumbs2/Gerard.Koninckx.et.freres.colonial.art.boul.Ypres.JPG}}

properties.name: Cinéma Congo
Cinéma Vendôme
properties.description:
The cinéma Vendôme was part of the Royal Trust and therefore is a part of Congolese heritage. [[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Trust_(Belgium)#Used_by_the_Royal_Family]]
source: Lucas Catherine, 2010, Promenade au Congo: petit guide anticolonial de Belgique

properties.name: Collectionneur Van Overstraeten
properties.description:
This is the house of collector Joseph Van Overstraeten. On the building he advertises himself as an 'ancien colonial' who buys and collects all kinds of old Congolese objects: masks, weapons, jewelry, documents, ivory... The building has three big windows. You can't really look inside and it has a kind of dodgy atmosphere, but in the windowsill you can see some objects (photographs, little statues) from his collection.

{{https://66.media.tumblr.com/dc10f5e30945367da24b651c432daa98/tumblr_pne91yiEZH1y7woi9o1_1280.jpg}}

properties.name: Former novitiate of the missionaries of Scheut
Keizerstraat 25 - Oldest house of the White Fathers (Witte Paters)
properties.description:
This is the oldest house of the White Fathers, also known as the society of the missionaries of Africa. The building is situated closeby the former docks where the missionaries would leave on boats to Africa and receive shipped goods. Up to this day the building is inhabited by the community of White Fathers.

{{http://www.lavigerie.be/local/cache-vignettes/L250xH179/keizerstantw2-8ef4f.jpg}}

{{https://66.media.tumblr.com/612f0a6e621b8b269a7a6377b3e245ad/tumblr_pnwinu02GK1y7woi9o1_1280.png}}
*Photograph of a few novices studying in '67. Note the map of Congo hanging in the background on the right.*

properties.name: Rue Cardinal Lavigerie
Rue de Tabora
Rue Renkin
properties.description:
Jules Renkin was the first Belgian minister of the Colonies after the annexation of Congo, from 1908 until 1918. He played an important role in reorganizing the administration of the colonization, and of course was the head responsible for the many atrocities that went down.

At first the area that is now called Matonge, went by the name of Renkin. After the "zaïrisation" under Mobutu, the name changed to Matonge, which is an area in Kinshasa. Only this street in Schaerbeek is still called after Jules Renkin.
According to Wikipedia his bust statue can still be found in the Belgian Federal Parliament.

{{https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Brussels%2C_Palais_de_la_Nation%2C_Jules_Renkin.jpg/220px-Brussels%2C_Palais_de_la_Nation%2C_Jules_Renkin.jpg}}

source: Catherine, Lucas. 2010. Promenade au Congo: Petit guide anticolonial de Belgique.
